image.altText: Pat Cummins, Cameron Green and Alex Carey laugh

items.synopsis: Australia wins the second Test at Lord's, despite a masterful innings from England captain Ben Stokes taking his side within touching distance of another Ashes miracle. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Australia survives Ben Stokes onslaught to win Lord's Test and take 2-0 Ashes lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The final margin was 43 runs. They certainly drew it out, but once the wicket of Ben Stokes happened, England were always going to fold and they did pretty quickly in the end all things up. Plenty to talk about, of course. We'll hear from some of the players very soon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia wins the second Test, takes a 2-0 lead

children.content: They certainly drew it out, but once the wicket of Ben Stokes happened, England were always going to fold and they did pretty quickly in the end all things up.
Plenty to talk about, of course. We'll hear from some of the players very soon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Starc finally goes full and straight and finally, belatedly, Australia gets the final wicket! Tongue stepped back and tries to steer the ball away to the off side and it's all over. Boos ring out around Lord's, but just like England, the fight has rather gone out of the genteel clientele of north London.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bowled him!

children.content: Starc finally goes full and straight and finally, belatedly, Australia gets the final wicket!
Tongue stepped back and tries to steer the ball away to the off side and it's all over.
Boos ring out around Lord's, but just like England, the fight has rather gone out of the genteel clientele of north London.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well Stuart Broad has been out there a long time, almost 2 hours, for his 11 runs, but he holes out to deep fine leg. Australia are just one away.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Stuart Broad is out!

children.content: Well Stuart Broad has been out there a long time, almost 2 hours, for his 11 runs, but he holes out to deep fine leg.

image.altText: Police tape visible on the scene of a mass shooting incident in Baltimore.

items.synopsis: The Baltimore Police Department said two people have died, three are in a critical condition and 25 others have been injured.

title.children: US police are investigating a mass shooting involving 30 victims

image.altText: A woman at a police press conference.

items.synopsis: Queensland Police hope an emotional appeal from the family of murdered Gold Coast father-of-two Matthew Berry will lead to some vital information about his death.

title.children: Family of murdered Gold Coast father Matthew Berry issue emotional plea

image.altText: A municipal police officer stands in front of a damaged home in France.

items.synopsis: The home of a Paris suburb mayor is ram-raided and set alight, while unrest spreads to neighbouring western Switzerland.

title.children: Home of French mayor ram-raided, while riots are echoed in Switzerland

image.altText: A young mother with long brown hair and glasses sitting on a playground with her young son

items.synopsis: As the National Disability Insurance Scheme marks 10 years, it's become apparent reform is needed. As the tussle to reign in costs intensifies, participants want the wider community to recognise the investment is life-saving and not a frivolous expense.

title.children: As the NDIS turns 10, this is what participants and their families want you to know about the scheme

image.altText: A man in suit at Parliament House in Canberra.

items.synopsis: A new special envoy to the Pacific is appointed as the government looks to strenghen relationships in the region.

title.children: Australia appoints special envoy to strengthen bonds with Pacific nations

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios holds tennis racquets at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios says he's fit to compete at Wimbledon but doesn't believe people should expect him to replicate last year's run to the final.

title.children: 'Brutal' year means 2022 finalist Kyrgios has tempered his Wimbledon expectations

image.altText: Pregnant woman

items.synopsis: In an Australian first, Victoria has opened its first free public egg and sperm bank, making it easier for hopeful parents to start a family. But fertility experts say the government's donation targets are "ambitious" with altruistic donors typically difficult to recruit.

title.children: Australia's first free sperm and egg bank opens with 'ambitious' donation targets

image.altText: A young girl smiles at bubbles blowing around the Come Together For Yes rally in Sydney

items.synopsis: Thousands take part in Yes vote events around the country as advocates lay out why Australia needs a Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'We need to do this': Yes campaigners rally around the country

image.altText: Two women police officers on a street

items.synopsis: It took 180 years for the first female police officer to be stationed in the rural town of Fingal. That milestone statistic has now doubled.

title.children: After 180 years, this police station just got its first female officers

image.altText: People sign an agreement.

items.synopsis: The deal between the University of South Australia and University of Adelaide, which comes after years of talks, will create a new institution with more than 70,000 students.

title.children: University merger deal reached to create one of Australia's largest education institutions

image.altText: A man in a black t-shirt stands in front of 6 microphones

items.synopsis: The man who beat Manny Pacquiao to take the WBO welterweight title in 2017 has taken up a new fight outside the ring.

title.children: Jeff Horn retires from the ring to focus on his 'biggest' fight yet

image.altText: A woman walks away from newspaper jobs in a rubbish bin

items.synopsis: According to some economists, we need more unemployment in Australia to get inflation under control. But, Gareth Hutchens asks, do they know how jobseekers are treated?

title.children: Economists want more unemployment. But do they care how the jobless will be treated?

image.altText: A group of dejected-looking Melbourne AFL players walk with hands on hips after losing a game.

items.synopsis: The top four remains open as Melbourne drops four points to GWS in Alice Springs, while West Coast falls just short of an incredible upset against St Kilda and the Blues take care of the Hawks at the MCG.

title.children: Top-four spot wide open after Giants stun Demons, Saints pip Eagles

image.altText: Three women and a man's face all smiling

items.synopsis: Since the dust settled on the pandemic, personal choice has replaced government mandates. So which of our COVID-19 habits did we keep, and which have we let slide?

title.children: Australia has now had seven waves of COVID, but lots of the habits we've learned have slipped

image.altText: Australia batter Nathan Lyon walks on the field during a Test with his helmet pushed back on his head.

items.synopsis: The injured spinner hits out at comments suggesting Australia would benefit from him being hit in the head while batting at Lord's.

title.children: 'I've lost one of my mates due to being hit in the head': Lyon hits out at Pietersen over concussion comments

image.altText: A rainbow over the Sydney Harbour Bridge with boats on the water

items.synopsis: A working holiday in Australia is back on the cards for British travellers over 30. What are the changes and what does it mean for Aussies in the UK?

title.children: UK travellers have five more years to apply for a working holiday visa in Australia. This is what has changed

image.altText: Several retail fireworks placed in front of a cardboard box.

items.synopsis: Authorities say two men were taken to hospital after the incident, which unfolded at an address in the Darwin rural area.

title.children: Darwin man loses hand in fireworks-related incident as firefighters respond to nearly 100 blazes

image.altText: Street signs mark the intersection of Constance and Ann streets in Brisbane's Fortitude Valley

items.synopsis: Queensland Police are appealing for witnesses after a gang of men wearing masks and balaclavas allegedly attacked patrons leaving venues in Fortitude Valley on Saturday night.

title.children: Masked men wanted after spate of late-night knife attacks in Brisbane

image.altText: A pot boils on a gas stove in a residential kitchen

items.synopsis: When Steven Secker's hot water heater broke, the pensioner was backed into a corner. Amid a growing push for households to electrify their appliances and move away from gas, social services warn people like Mr Secker could be left behind in any transition.

title.children: Getting off gas is meant to be the future, but transitioning your home comes with a cost

image.altText: A young Chinese man standing in front of Sydney Opera House.

items.synopsis: A compulsory online module is teaching international students at Australian universities about consent and inspiring some to take their new-found sex education back home. But Chinese students say there's still a long way to go.

title.children: Francis never got taught how to use condoms in China. Then he came to Australia

image.altText: A model wearing white walks along a catwalk behind a purple background that reads ELLERY

items.synopsis: Celebrated fashion designer Kym Ellery defends her handling of the 2019 collapse of her Australian business.

title.children: Designer Kym Ellery's edgy outfits won over celebrities. Her 2019 fashion business collapse left suppliers owed millions

image.altText: Two tea cups on a kitchen sink, the one to the left contains slightly brown water while the one to the left is clear.

items.synopsis: The quality of tap water in this rural town is so poor it's undrinkable, and residents have concerns about even bathing in it.

title.children: This isn't a cup of tea, it's the tap water being supplied to a frustrated Queensland community

image.altText: Medical staff in hazmat suits carry patient in a clear container

items.synopsis: Highly trained doctors and nurses at the facility in Sydney's west will provide care to those with diseases so dangerous they're likely to kill more than half of those that contract them.

title.children: 'Prepared for worst': Inside Australia's new line of defence against next deadly disease outbreak

image.altText: Senator Penny Wong with a serious expression.

items.synopsis: As Ukraine continues to lobby Australia for Hawkei and Bushmaster armoured vehicles, the ambassador makes a public call for Foreign Minister Penny Wong to see Kyiv with her own eyes.

title.children: Ukraine ambassador asks Foreign Minister Penny Wong to visit Kyiv amid calls for more weaponry

image.altText: A smiling Australian Opals basketballer hugs a teammates as they celebrate a win.

items.synopsis: Australia secures a bronze medal at the women's Asia Cup basketball tournament with an emphatic 81-59 win over New Zealand.

title.children: Opals claim Asia Cup bronze with win over New Zealand

image.altText: Rachel Perkins with an award.

items.synopsis: Black excellence and community leadership are honoured at the 2023 National NAIDOC Week Awards in Brisbane.

title.children: ‘Stand with us, Australia’: NAIDOC Award winner’s message on the Voice

image.altText: A beached whale with a lady on the phone wearing an orange vest in the background.

items.synopsis: Efforts are underway to bury the whale carcass on site near Lennox Head, prompting concerns for an upcoming surfing competition.

title.children: Excavator brought in to bury 20-tonne beached whale carcass on NSW coast

image.altText: A mural depicting the Wagner Group painted on a building in Belgrade, Serbia

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin's darkest battles are being carried out by a number of private armies run by Russia's elite, but after an attempted uprising, the Russian president is facing the reality they could turn on him, writes Isabella Higgins.

title.children: Could Putin face another mutiny from his mercenaries? Wagner was just one of the pay-to-kill groups fighting for Russia

image.altText: Elon Musk with his hands clasped together.

items.synopsis: Twitter users will now be locked out of the platform for the day if they read more than their daily post allowance.

title.children: Elon Musk announces limit for how many posts users can read on Twitter

image.altText: Two women holding a 160-year-old Aboriginal spear.

items.synopsis: A wooden combat spear lost in a fatal fight between an Aboriginal man and a white settler 160 years ago has been returned to its original owners, in what the families say is an act of reconciliation.

title.children: Aboriginal combat spear lost in fight 160 years ago returned to original owners

image.altText: A man on a mountain bike in mid-air as he rides along a dirt track.

items.synopsis: Cycling is the country's most injurious sport, while equestrian activities are the most likely to harm women, according to the latest national data.

title.children: Cuts, bruises and broken bones, but cyclists and horseriders keep coming back
